name: nitrile-compound production | nitrile-compound | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8215/documentation

This dataset represents the production of nitrile-compounds. Nitriles are herbicides with a nitrile group and are produced by halogenation and nitrilation of an aromate. This dataset was calculated from the arithmetic mean of all inputs and outputs of the production of bromoxynil, chlorothalonil, dichlobenil, and ioxynil. The raw materials are modelled with a stoichiometric calculations, while the energy consumption is modelled with data from a similar process. The emissions are estimated and the infrastructure is included with a default value.;References:;Nemecek T. & Kägi T. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Swiss and European Agricultural Production Systems. Final report ecoinvent V2.0 No. 15a. Agroscope Reckenholz-Taenikon Research Station ART, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Zurich and Dübendorf, CH.;Gendorf (2016) Umwelterklärung 2015, Werk Gendorf Industriepark, www.gendorf.de.

From reception of precursors at the factory gate.

This activity ends with nitrile-compounds at the factory gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. The dataset doesn't include emulsives, additives etc.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time of publications. Some values are based on data published by the Gendorf factory that were collected between 2011 and 2015. The time period has been adjusted accordingly. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe but is assumed to be representative of the global production. Some values are based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. These are assumed to be valid for this geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset was calculated from the arithmetic mean of all inputs and outputs of the production of bromoxynil, chlorothalonil, dichlobenil, and ioxynil.;Bromoxynil is produced in four steps from phenol:;C6H6O + CHCl3 + KOH → C7H6O2 + 2 HCl + KCl;C7H6O2 + 2 Br2 → C7H4Br2O2 + HBr;C7H4Br2O2 + NH3O → C7H5Br2NO2 + H2O;C7H5Br2NO2 → C7H2Br2NO + H2O;Precursors that are used for the bromoxynil production are hydroxylamine ((NH3OH)2SO4) and nitrous dioxide (NO2).;Chlorothalonil is produced in three steps from xylene: ;2 C8H10 + 2 NH3 + 3 O2 → 2 C8H7N + 6 H2O;2 C8H7N + 2 NH3 + 3 O2 → 2 C8H4N2 + 6 H2O;C8H4N2 + 4 Cl2 → C8Cl4N2 + 4 HCl;Dichlobenil is produced in four steps from o-dichlorobenzene:;C7H8 + 4 Cl2 → C7H4Cl4 + 4 HCl;C7H4Cl3 + H2O → C7H4Cl2O + 2 HCl;C7H4Cl2O + NH3O → C7H5Cl2NO + H2O;C7H5Cl2NO → C7H3Cl2N + H2O;Precursors that are used for the dichlobenil production are hydroxylamine (NH3O) and nitrous dioxide (NO2).;Ioxynil is produced in four steps from phenol:;C6H6O + CHCl3 + KOH → C7H6O2 + 2 HCl + KCl;C7H6O2 + 2 I2 → C7H4I2O2 + HI;C7H4I2O2 + NH3O → C7H5I2NO2 + H2O;C7H5I2NO2 → C7H2I2NO + H2O;Precursors that are used for the ioxynil production are hydroxylamine (NH3O) and nitrous dioxide (NO2).;Precursors: ;Hydroxylamine (NH3O) is produced in five steps from ammonia:;4 NH3 + 5 O2 → 4 NO + 6 H2O;NO2 + NO + (NH4)2CO3 → 2 N2H4O2 + CO2;N2H4O2 + 2 SO2 + NH3 + H2O → H9N3O7S2;2 H9N3O7S2 + 2 NH3 + 4 H2O → (NH3OH)2SO4 + 3 (NH4)2SO4;(NH3OH)2SO4 + 2 NaOH → 2 NH3O + Na2SO4 + 2 H2O;Nitrous dioxide (NO2) is produced by oxidation of nitrogen:;2 NO + O2 → 2 NO2
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography RER. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature data. Some values are calculated based on data from a large chemical factory located in Germany. For more details, see the comments of the exchanges.

exchanges.description: Nitrile-compounds can have different modes of action. Chorothalonil, which is an fungicide, has a multi-site contact activity; bromoxynil, ioxyni, which are herbicides, act as inhibitors of photosynthesis at photosystem II site B; and dichlobenil, which is also a herbicide, acts as an inhibitor of cell wall synthesis site A.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to water/unspecified

exchanges.description: Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. This value is a 5-year average of data (2011 - 2015) published by the Gendorf factory (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de),  (Gendorf, 2015, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de),  (Gendorf, 2014, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The amount of nitrogen used per kg of chemical substance produced is calculated using literature data published by the Gendorf factory based in Germany, which produces a wide range of chemical substances. The factory produced 1657400 tonnes of chemical substances in the year 2015 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de) and 740000 tonnes of intermediate products. The reported amount of nitrogen used in 2015 was 33512400 Nm3 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). One Nm3 of nitrogen is equal to 1.2506 kg. The resulting amount of nitrogen - the 5-year average (2011 - 2015, weighted by production volume) is 0.019 kg/kg. Nitrogen is mainly used during the production of chemicals for 'blanketing', which is the process of applying gas to the vapour space of a container or vessel in order to control its composition.

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on the assumption that 0.2% of volatile input materials is emitted to air occurring from the purge vent, the destillation vent and fugitive emission sources. Remaining gases like CH4 or CO are oxidated to CO2. The carbon contained in the removed carbon compounds from wastewater treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air (assuming  a removal efficiency of 90%).

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from the calculation of an average consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ/kg), and a resulting amount of electricity of 0.333 kWh for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that includes 38% electricity.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:
Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from the calculation of an average consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ/kg), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that includes 50% natural gas.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:
Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

flow.name: Toluene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. Furthermore, for this dataset, the infrastructure amount is accounted for each production step. This may be an overestimation in some multistep syntheses.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.'

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from the calculation of an average consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ/kg), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that includes 12% steam from external energy sources.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:
Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003
